from lollms import AIPersonality, lollms_path
from lollms.binding import BindingConfig, LLMBinding
import shutil
import yaml
import importlib
from pathlib import Path
import sys

class BindingBuilder:
    def build_binding(self, bindings_path: Path, cfg: BindingConfig)->LLMBinding:
        binding_path = Path(bindings_path) / cfg["binding_name"]
        # first find out if there is a requirements.txt file
        install_file_name = "install.py"
        install_script_path = binding_path / install_file_name
        if install_script_path.exists():
            module_name = install_file_name[:-3]  # Remove the ".py" extension
            module_spec = importlib.util.spec_from_file_location(module_name, str(install_script_path))
            module = importlib.util.module_from_spec(module_spec)
            module_spec.loader.exec_module(module)
            if hasattr(module, "Install"):
                module.Install(cfg)
        # define the full absolute path to the module
        absolute_path = binding_path.resolve()
        # infer the module name from the file path
        module_name = binding_path.stem
        # use importlib to load the module from the file path
        loader = importlib.machinery.SourceFileLoader(module_name, str(absolute_path / "__init__.py"))
        binding_module = loader.load_module()
        binding_class = getattr(binding_module, binding_module.binding_name)
        return binding_class
    

class ModelBuilder:
    def __init__(self, binding_class:LLMBinding, config:BindingConfig):
        self.binding_class = binding_class
        self.model = None
        self.build_model(config) 

    def build_model(self, cfg: BindingConfig):
        self.model = self.binding_class(cfg)

    def get_model(self):
        return self.model


class MainMenu:
    def __init__(self, conversation):
        self.binding_infs = []
        self.conversation = conversation

    def show_menu(self, options):
        print("Menu:")
        for index, option in enumerate(options):
            print(f"{index + 1} - {option}")
        choice = input("Enter your choice: ")
        return int(choice) if choice.isdigit() else -1

    def select_binding(self):
        bindings_list = []
        for p in (lollms_path/"bindings_zoo").iterdir():
            if p.is_dir():
                with open(p/"binding_card.yaml", "r") as f:
                    card = yaml.safe_load(f)
                with open(p/"models.yaml", "r") as f:
                    models = yaml.safe_load(f)
                entry=f"{card['name']} (by {card['author']})"
                bindings_list.append(entry)
                entry={
                    "name":p.name,
                    "card":card,
                    "models":models
                }
                self.binding_infs.append(entry)

        choice = self.show_menu(bindings_list)
        if 1 <= choice <= len(self.binding_infs):
            print(f"You selected binding: {self.binding_infs[choice - 1]['name']}")
            self.conversation.config['binding_name']=self.binding_infs[choice - 1]['name']
            self.conversation.load_binding()
            self.conversation.config.save_config()
        else:
            print("Invalid choice!")

    def select_model(self):
        models_list = [m.name for m in (lollms_path/"models"/self.conversation.config['binding_name']).iterdir()] + ["Install model"]
        choice = self.show_menu(models_list)
        if 1 <= choice <= len(models_list)-1:
            print(f"You selected model: {models_list[choice - 1]}")
            self.conversation.config['model_name']=models_list[choice - 1]
            self.conversation.load_model()
            self.conversation.config.save_config()
        elif choice <= len(models_list):
            url = input("Give a URL to the model to be downloaded :")
            self.conversation.config.download_model(url)
            self.select_model()
        else:
            print("Invalid choice!")

    def select_personality(self):
        personality_languages = [p.stem for p in (lollms_path/"personalities_zoo").iterdir()]
        print("Select language")
        choice = self.show_menu(personality_languages)
        if 1 <= choice <= len(personality_languages):
            language = personality_languages[choice - 1]
            print(f"You selected language: {language}")
            personality_categories = [p.stem for p in lollms_path/"personalities_zoo"/language]
            print("Select category")
            choice = self.show_menu(personality_categories)
            if 1 <= choice <= len(personality_categories):
                category = personality_categories[choice - 1]
                print(f"You selected category: {category}")

                personality_names = [p.stem for p in lollms_path/"personalities_zoo"/language/category]
                print("Select personality")
                choice = self.show_menu(personality_names)
                if 1 <= choice <= len(personality_names):
                    name = personality_names[choice - 1]
                    print(f"You selected personality: {name}")
                    self.conversation.config["personalities"]=[f"{language}/{category}/{name}"]
                    self.conversation.load_personality()
                    self.conversation.config.save_config()
                else:
                    print("Invalid choice!")

            else:
                print("Invalid choice!")

        else:
            print("Invalid choice!")

    def main_menu(self):
        while True:
            print("\nMain Menu:")
            print("1 - Select Binding")
            print("2 - Select Model")
            print("3 - Select Personality")
            print("0 - Exit")
            choice = input("Enter your choice: ")
            if choice == "1":
                self.select_binding()
            elif choice == "2":
                self.select_model()
            elif choice == "3":
                self.select_personality()
            elif choice == "0":
                print("Exiting the program...")
                break
            else:
                print("Invalid choice! Try again.")

class Conversation:
    def __init__(self):
        # url = "https://huggingface.co/TheBloke/Manticore-13B-GGML/resolve/main/Manticore-13B.ggmlv3.q4_0.bin"
        # personality_path = "english/generic/lollms"
        # model_name = url.split("/")[-1]

        # Change configuration
        original = lollms_path / "configs/config.yaml"
        local = lollms_path / "configs/local_config.yaml"
        if not local.exists():
            shutil.copy(original, local)
        self.cfg_path = local

        self.config = BindingConfig(self.cfg_path)
        # load binding
        self.load_binding()

        # Load model
        self.load_model()
        # cfg.binding_name = llm_binding.binding_folder_name
        # cfg.model_name = model_name

        # Load personality
        self.load_personality()

        # If there is a disclaimer, show it
        if self.personality.disclaimer != "":
            print("\nDisclaimer")
            print(self.personality.disclaimer)
            print()

        if self.personality.welcome_message:
            print(self.personality.welcome_message)
        

    def load_binding(self):
        try:
            self.binding_class = BindingBuilder().build_binding(lollms_path/"bindings_zoo", self.config)
        except Exception as ex:
            print(ex)
            print(f"Couldn't find binding. Please verify your configuration file at {self.cfg_path} or use the next menu to select a valid binding")
            MainMenu(self).select_binding()

    def load_model(self):
        if not self.config.check_model_existance():
            print(f"No model found for binding {self.config['binding_name']}")
            print("Please select a valid model or install a new one from a url")
            MainMenu(self).select_model()

from lollms import AIPersonality, lollms_path
from lollms.binding import BindingConfig, LLMBinding
import shutil
import yaml
import importlib
from pathlib import Path
import sys

class BindingBuilder:
    def build_binding(self, bindings_path: Path, cfg: BindingConfig)->LLMBinding:
        binding_path = Path(bindings_path) / cfg["binding_name"]
        # first find out if there is a requirements.txt file
        install_file_name = "install.py"
        install_script_path = binding_path / install_file_name
        if install_script_path.exists():
            module_name = install_file_name[:-3]  # Remove the ".py" extension
            module_spec = importlib.util.spec_from_file_location(module_name, str(install_script_path))
            module = importlib.util.module_from_spec(module_spec)
            module_spec.loader.exec_module(module)
            if hasattr(module, "Install"):
                module.Install(cfg)
        # define the full absolute path to the module
        absolute_path = binding_path.resolve()
        # infer the module name from the file path
        module_name = binding_path.stem
        # use importlib to load the module from the file path
        loader = importlib.machinery.SourceFileLoader(module_name, str(absolute_path / "__init__.py"))
        binding_module = loader.load_module()
        binding_class = getattr(binding_module, binding_module.binding_name)
        return binding_class
    

class ModelBuilder:
    def __init__(self, binding_class:LLMBinding, config:BindingConfig):
        self.binding_class = binding_class
        self.model = None
        self.build_model(config) 

    def build_model(self, cfg: BindingConfig):
        self.model = self.binding_class(cfg)

    def get_model(self):
        return self.model


class MainMenu:
    def __init__(self, conversation):
        self.binding_infs = []
        self.conversation = conversation

    def show_menu(self, options):
        print("Menu:")
        for index, option in enumerate(options):
            print(f"{index + 1} - {option}")
        choice = input("Enter your choice: ")
        return int(choice) if choice.isdigit() else -1

    def select_binding(self):
        bindings_list = []
        for p in (lollms_path/"bindings_zoo").iterdir():
            if p.is_dir():
                with open(p/"binding_card.yaml", "r") as f:
                    card = yaml.safe_load(f)
                with open(p/"models.yaml", "r") as f:
                    models = yaml.safe_load(f)
                entry=f"{card['name']} (by {card['author']})"
                bindings_list.append(entry)
                entry={
                    "name":p.name,
                    "card":card,
                    "models":models
                }
                self.binding_infs.append(entry)

        choice = self.show_menu(bindings_list)
        if 1 <= choice <= len(self.binding_infs):
            print(f"You selected binding: {self.binding_infs[choice - 1]['name']}")
            self.conversation.config['binding_name']=self.binding_infs[choice - 1]['name']
            self.conversation.load_binding()
            self.conversation.config.save_config()
        else:
            print("Invalid choice!")

    def select_model(self):
        models_list = [m.name for m in (lollms_path/"models"/self.conversation.config['binding_name']).iterdir()] + ["Install model"]
        choice = self.show_menu(models_list)
        if 1 <= choice <= len(models_list)-1:
            print(f"You selected model: {models_list[choice - 1]}")
            self.conversation.config['model_name']=models_list[choice - 1]
            self.conversation.load_model()
            self.conversation.config.save_config()
        elif choice <= len(models_list):
            url = input("Give a URL to the model to be downloaded :")
            self.conversation.config.download_model(url)
            self.select_model()
        else:
            print("Invalid choice!")

    def select_personality(self):
        personality_languages = [p.stem for p in (lollms_path/"personalities_zoo").iterdir()]
        print("Select language")
        choice = self.show_menu(personality_languages)
        if 1 <= choice <= len(personality_languages):
            language = personality_languages[choice - 1]
            print(f"You selected language: {language}")
            personality_categories = [p.stem for p in lollms_path/"personalities_zoo"/language]
            print("Select category")
            choice = self.show_menu(personality_categories)
            if 1 <= choice <= len(personality_categories):
                category = personality_categories[choice - 1]
                print(f"You selected category: {category}")

                personality_names = [p.stem for p in lollms_path/"personalities_zoo"/language/category]
                print("Select personality")
                choice = self.show_menu(personality_names)
                if 1 <= choice <= len(personality_names):
                    name = personality_names[choice - 1]
                    print(f"You selected personality: {name}")
                    self.conversation.config["personalities"]=[f"{language}/{category}/{name}"]
                    self.conversation.load_personality()
                    self.conversation.config.save_config()
                else:
                    print("Invalid choice!")

            else:
                print("Invalid choice!")

        else:
            print("Invalid choice!")

    def main_menu(self):
        while True:
            print("\nMain Menu:")
            print("1 - Select Binding")
            print("2 - Select Model")
            print("3 - Select Personality")
            print("0 - Exit")
            choice = input("Enter your choice: ")
            if choice == "1":
                self.select_binding()
            elif choice == "2":
                self.select_model()
            elif choice == "3":
                self.select_personality()
            elif choice == "0":
                print("Exiting the program...")
                break
            else:
                print("Invalid choice! Try again.")

module 'urllib' has no attribute 'request'

The error message you encountered suggests that the 'urllib' module does not have an attribute named 'request'. This error typically occurs when you are trying to use the 'request' submodule from the 'urllib' module but mistakenly reference it as an attribute of 'urllib' itself.

Starting from Python 3, the 'urllib' module was split into several submodules, including 'urllib.request', 'urllib.parse', and 'urllib.error'. This change was made to enhance modularity and improve code organization.

To resolve the issue, you should import and use the 'request' submodule explicitly. Here's an example of how you can import and use it correctly:

```python
from urllib.request import urlopen

# Example usage
response = urlopen('https://www.example.com')
data = response.read()
print(data)
```

In the above example, we import the 'urlopen' function from the 'urllib.request' submodule. Then, we can use 'urlopen' to open a URL and retrieve the response.

Make sure you're using the correct import statement for the specific functionality you need from the 'urllib' module.

Then, we use the `urlretrieve` function and provide the URL, the complete file path (combining the `folder_path` and the filename extracted from the URL using `url.split("/")[-1]`), and the optional `reporthook` argument to track the progress of the download. Make sure you have the necessary permissions to access the specified folder, and the file URL is valid.

    model_name = url.split("/")[-1]

    # Change configuration
    original = lollms_path / "configs/config.yaml"
    local = lollms_path / "configs/local_config.yaml"
    if not local.exists():
        shutil.copy(original, local)
    cfg_path = local

    cfg = BindingConfig(cfg_path)
    cfg.binding_name = llm_binding.binding_folder_name
    cfg.model_name = model_name
    if not cfg.check_model_existance():
        cfg.download_model(url)

    model = build_model(cfg)

            self.personality.link_text
        )

        while True:
            try:
                prompt = input("You: ")
                if prompt == "exit":
                    return
                if prompt == "menu":
                    main_menu = MainMenu()
                    main_menu.main_menu()
                    continue
                if prompt == '':
                    continue

                if self.personality.processor is not None:
                    preprocessed_prompt = self.personality.processor.process_model_input(prompt)

                    full_discussion += (
                        self.personality.user_message_prefix +
                        preprocessed_prompt +
                        self.personality.link_text +
                        self.personality.ai_message_prefix
                    )
                else:
                    full_discussion += (
                        self.personality.user_message_prefix +
                        prompt +
                        self.personality.link_text +
                        self.personality.ai_message_prefix
                    )

                print(f"{self.personality.name}:", end='')

                def callback(text, type=None):
                    print(text, end="", flush=True)
                    return True

                output = self.personality.model.generate(full_discussion, callback=callback)
                print("\n")

                if self.personality.processor is not None:
                    if self.personality.processor.process_model_output is not None:
                        output = self.personality.processor.process_model_output(output)

            except KeyboardInterrupt:
                print("Keyboard interrupt detected.\nBye")
                break

        print("Done")
        print(f"{self.personality}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    # Choose your model (uncomment the model you want to use)
    url = "https://huggingface.co/TheBloke/Manticore-13B-GGML/resolve/main/Manticore-13B.ggmlv3.q4_0.bin"
    personality_path = "english/generic/lollms"

    personality_setup = PersonalitySetup()
    personality_setup.setup_model(url, personality_path)

    print("█          █        █       █▄ ▄█▄ ▄█       ")
    print("█     ▄▀▀▄ █        █       █ ▀   ▀ █  ▄▀▀▄ ")
    print("█     █  █ █        █       █       █  ▀▄▄  ")
    print("█▄▄▄▄ ▀▄▄▀ █▄▄▄▄▄   █▄▄▄▄   █       █  ▄▄▄▀ ")

    print("Version: 1.0")
    print("By : ParisNeo")

    print("Base commands:")
    print("└ commands:")
    print("   ├ exit: exists the console")
    print("   └ menu: shows main menu")
    # If there is a disclaimer, show it
    if personality_setup.personality.disclaimer != "":
        print("\nDisclaimer")
        print(personality_setup.personality.disclaimer)
        print()

    if personality_setup.personality.welcome_message:
        print(personality_setup.personality.welcome_message)

    conversation = Conversation(personality_setup.personality)
    conversation.start_conversation()
```

In the converted code, the functionality is

divided into separate classes. The `ModelBuilder` class is responsible for building the model, while the `PersonalitySetup` class handles the setup of the model and personality. The `MainMenu` class handles the main menu functionality, and the `Conversation` class is responsible for starting and managing the conversation. The main program flow is organized under the `__main__` block at the end.

Note: The conversion assumes that the dependencies (`lollms`, `lollms.binding`, `lollms.bindings_zoo.llama_cpp_official`, `lollms.bindings_zoo.llama_cpp_official.install`, `shutil`, and `yaml`) are imported and available in the new code.

in python how to put the types of multiple outputs in a function?

In Python, you can use type hints to specify the types of multiple outputs in a function. Type hints provide a way to annotate the types of variables, function arguments, and return values. You can use type hints to indicate the types of multiple return values from a function.

Here's an example of how you can use type hints for multiple return values in a function:

```python
def process_data(data: List[int]) -> Tuple[int, float, str]:
    """
    Process the input data and return multiple values.
    """
    # Perform some operations on the data
    total = sum(data)
    average = total / len(data)
    message = "Data processed successfully."

    return total, average, message

# Call the function
result = process_data([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])

# Access the individual return values
total_value, average_value, message_text = result

# Print the values
print("Total:", total_value)
print("Average:", average_value)
print("Message:", message_text)
```

In the example above, the function `process_data` takes a list of integers as input and returns three values: an integer (`total`), a float (`average`), and a string (`message`). The type hints are specified using `List[int]` for the input parameter and `Tuple[int, float, str]` for the return type.

Note that type hints are optional in Python and are not enforced at runtime. They are mainly used for static analysis and code readability.
do i need to import Tuple?

Yes, if you want to use the `Tuple` type hint, you need to import it from the `typing` module. The `Tuple` type hint is used to specify a tuple with a fixed number of elements and their respective types.

Here's an updated version of the previous example, including the necessary import statement:

```python
from typing import List, Tuple

def process_data(data: List[int]) -> Tuple[int, float, str]:

    total = sum(data)
    average = total / len(data)
    message = "Data processed successfully."

    return total, average, message

# Call the function

# Access the individual return values
total_value, average_value, message_text = result

# Print the values
print("Total:", total_value)
print("Average:", average_value)
print("Message:", message_text)
```

In this updated code, the line `from typing import List, Tuple` imports the `List` and `Tuple` types from the `typing` module. This allows you to use `Tuple[int, float, str]` as the return type hint for the `process_data` function, specifying that the function will return a tuple containing an integer, a float, and a string in that order.

Make sure you have the `typing` module installed in your Python environment to use the `Tuple` type hint.
how to copy adict?

To copy a dictionary in Python, you can use the `copy` module or the built-in `dict()` constructor. Here are two common methods to copy a dictionary:

1. Using the `copy` module:
```python
import copy

original_dict = {"key1": "value1", "key2": "value2"}

# Shallow copy
shallow_copy_dict = copy.copy(original_dict)

# Deep copy
deep_copy_dict = copy.deepcopy(original_dict)
```

In the code above, `copy.copy()` creates a shallow copy of the original dictionary, while `copy.deepcopy()` creates a deep copy. A shallow copy creates a new dictionary object, but the references to the objects inside the dictionary are still shared. A deep copy, on the other hand, creates a completely independent copy of the dictionary and its contents.

2. Using the `dict()` constructor:
```python
original_dict = {"key1": "value1", "key2": "value2"}

# Shallow copy
shallow_copy_dict = dict(original_dict)

# Deep copy
deep_copy_dict = dict(original_dict)
```

In this method, you use the `dict()` constructor to create a new dictionary based on the original dictionary. Both `shallow_copy_dict` and `deep_copy_dict` will be copies of the original dictionary, but the behavior of shallow and deep copying is the same as explained earlier.

Regardless of which method you choose, keep in mind that if the dictionary contains mutable objects as values (e.g., lists, other dictionaries), a deep copy is necessary to ensure that the copied dictionary is completely independent of the original one.
how to use rest client in vscode to interact with socketio server?

To interact with a Socket.IO server using the REST client in Visual Studio Code (VSCode), you can use the `http` or `socket.io` library for making HTTP requests. Here's a step-by-step guide on how to set up and use the REST client in VSCode to interact with a Socket.IO server:

1. Install the REST Client extension in VSCode:
   - Open the Extensions view in VSCode by clicking on the square icon on the left sidebar or by using the shortcut `Ctrl+Shift+X`.
   - Search for "REST Client" in the search bar.
   - Click on the "REST Client" extension by Huachao Mao and click "Install".

2. Create a new `.http` file:
   - Create a new file in your workspace with the `.http` extension (e.g., `socketio.http`).

3. Specify the Socket.IO server URL and headers:
   - In the `.http` file, add the following lines to specify the server URL and headers:
     ```http
     @socketioURL = http://localhost:8000  // Replace with your Socket.IO server URL
     
     // Common headers if required
     @headers = {
       "Content-Type": "application/json"
     }
     ```

4. Establish a connection with the Socket.IO server:
   - To establish a connection with the Socket.IO server, you need to send an HTTP request to the `/socket.io/` endpoint. Add the following line to the `.http` file:
     ```http
     GET {{socketioURL}}/socket.io/ HTTP/1.1
     ```

5. Perform Socket.IO events and actions:
   - After establishing the connection, you can perform various Socket.IO events and actions using the REST client. Here are a few examples:

     ```http
     // Emit an event
     POST {{socketioURL}}/socket.io/?EIO=3&transport=polling HTTP/1.1
     @headers
     Content-Length: 62

     42["event_name", {"param1": "value1", "param2": "value2"}]

     // Send a message
     POST {{socketioURL}}/socket.io/?EIO=3&transport=polling HTTP/1.1
     @headers
     Content-Length: 31

     42["message", "Hello, Socket.IO!"]

     // Join a room
     POST {{socketioURL}}/socket.io/?EIO=3&transport=polling HTTP/1.1
     @headers
     Content-Length: 28

     42["join", "room_name"]

     // Leave a room
     POST {{socketioURL}}/socket.io/?EIO=3&transport=polling HTTP/1.1
     @headers
     Content-Length: 29

     42["leave", "room_name"]
     ```

     Note: The examples above assume the polling transport method. Depending on your Socket.IO server configuration, you may need to adjust the transport method or include additional parameters.

6. Send requests and view responses:
   - To send the requests and view the responses, use the "Send Request" button that appears above each request in the `.http` file. Alternatively, you can use the `Ctrl+Alt+R` shortcut to send the entire file.

7. View the server responses:
   - The responses from the Socket.IO server will be displayed in the right-hand side panel of the `.http` file. You can expand the responses to see the details.

By following these steps, you can use the REST client in VSCode to interact with a Socket.IO server and perform various events and actions. Remember

        ]

    # Other arguments...
)
```

In the `package_data` dictionary, you specify the package name as the key (in this case, an empty string `""` for the root package), and a list of file patterns as the value. The `"*"` pattern includes all files, and you can add additional patterns to exclude specific files or patterns.

Make sure to place this code snippet in the appropriate location in your script, and adjust the file patterns and package names according to your project structure.

import os
from pathlib import Path
from typing import Union

import setuptools


def recursive_files(directory: str) -> list[str]:
    file_list = []
    for root, _, files in os.walk(directory):
        for file in files:
            file_path = os.path.join(root, file)
            file_list.append(file_path)
    return file_list

write a function that takes a path then returns a list of all files of the folder recursively.

Certainly! Here's a function that takes a path and returns a list of all files within that folder and its subdirectories recursively:

```python
import os


def get_all_files(path):
    file_list = []
    for root, directories, files in os.walk(path):
        for file in files:
            file_path = os.path.join(root, file)
            file_list.append(file_path)
    return file_list
```

You can use this function by passing the desired path as an argument. It will return a list containing the paths of all files found within the folder and its subdirectories.

Here's an example of how you can use the function:

```python
folder_path = '/path/to/folder'
files = get_all_files(folder_path)
print(files)
```

Replace `'/path/to/folder'` with the actual path of the folder you want to scan. The function will traverse the directory recursively and provide you with a list of all the file paths it finds.

Note that the function only retrieves file paths and does not include directories in the returned list.
use pathlib

Certainly! Here's an updated version of the function that uses the `pathlib` module to work with file paths:

```python
from pathlib import Path


def get_all_files(path):
    path = Path(path)
    file_list = []
    for file_path in path.rglob('*'):
        if file_path.is_file():
            file_list.append(str(file_path))
    return file_list
```

This version of the function takes advantage of the `rglob()` method provided by `pathlib.Path`. It recursively traverses the directory tree, yielding `Path` objects for each file and directory found. The function checks if each `Path` object represents a file using the `is_file()` method before adding it to the `file_list`.

You can use this function in the same way as before:

```python
folder_path = '/path/to/folder'
files = get_all_files(folder_path)
print(files)
```

Replace `'/path/to/folder'` with the actual path of the folder you want to scan. The function will return a list of all the file paths within the folder and its subdirectories.

Using `pathlib` provides a more concise and elegant way to work with file paths in Python.

        self.initialize_routes()

    def initialize_routes(self):
        @self.socketio.on('connect')

            client_id = request.sid
            self.clients[client_id] = {"namespace": request.namespace, "full_discussion_blocks": []}
            print(f'Client connected with session ID: {client_id}')

        @self.socketio.on('disconnect')
        def handle_disconnect():
            client_id = request.sid
            if client_id in self.clients:
                del self.clients[client_id]

        @self.socketio.on('list_personalities')

    def build_model(self, bindings_path: Path, cfg: BindingConfig):
        binding_path = Path(bindings_path) / cfg["binding_name"]
        # first find out if there is a requirements.txt file
        install_file_name = "install.py"
        install_script_path = binding_path / install_file_name
        if install_script_path.exists():
            module_name = install_file_name[:-3]  # Remove the ".py" extension
            module_spec = importlib.util.spec_from_file_location(module_name, str(install_script_path))
            module = importlib.util.module_from_spec(module_spec)
            module_spec.loader.exec_module(module)
            if hasattr(module, "Install"):
                module.Install(self.config)
        # define the full absolute path to the module
        absolute_path = binding_path.resolve()
        # infer the module name from the file path
        module_name = binding_path.stem
        # use importlib to load the module from the file path
        loader = importlib.machinery.SourceFileLoader(module_name, str(absolute_path / "__init__.py"))
        binding_module = loader.load_module()
        binding_class = getattr(binding_module, binding_module.binding_name)

        model = binding_class(cfg)
        return model

            self.config.model_name = args.model_name

        model = self.build_model(args.bindings_path, self.config)
        self.models.append(model)

        self.personalities["default_personality"] = AIPersonality()

        for p in self.config.personalities:
            personality = AIPersonality(self.config.personalities_path/p)
            self.personalities[personality.name] = personality

        print("running...")
        self.socketio.run(self.app, host=args.host, port=args.port)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    server = AIPersonalityServer()
    server.run()

# AIPersonalityServer

AIPersonalityServer is a text generation server based on the LOL-LM (LOL Language Model) system. It provides an API for generating text using various AI models and personalities. This README.md file provides an overview of the server and instructions on how to install and use it.

## Features

- Generate text using AI models and personalities
- Supports multiple AI models and personalities
- WebSocket-based communication using Flask-SocketIO
- Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) enabled
- Customizable through configuration files
- Easy installation and setup

## Installation

You can install AIPersonalityServer using pip. Make sure you have Python 3.7 or above installed.

```shell
pip install lollms-server
```

## Usage

Once installed, you can run the server using the `lollms-server` command. The server accepts several command-line arguments to configure its behavior:

- `--host` or `-hst`: Specify the host name (default: localhost)
- `--port` or `-prt`: Specify the port number (default: 9600)
- `--config` or `-cfg`: Path to the configuration file (default: None)
- `--bindings_path` or `-bp`: Path to the Bindings folder (default: ./bindings_zoo)
- `--personalities_path` or `-pp`: Path to the personalities folder (default: ./personalities_zoo)
- `--models_path` or `-mp`: Path to the models folder (default: ./models)
- `--binding_name` or `-b`: Binding to be used by default (default: llama_cpp_official)
- `--model_name` or `-m`: Model name (default: Manticore-13B.ggmlv3.q4_0.bin)
- `--personality_full_name` or `-p`: Personality path relative to the personalities folder (default: personality)

To start the server, open a terminal or command prompt and run:

```shell
lollms-server
```

By default, the server listens on http://localhost:9600/. You can access the server using any WebSocket client or use the provided web interface.

## API Endpoints

The server exposes the following WebSocket-based API endpoints:

- `connect`: Triggered when a client connects to the server.
- `disconnect`: Triggered when a client disconnects from the server.
- `list_personalities`: Request the list of available personalities.
- `add_personality`: Add a new personality.
- `generate_text`: Generate text using the specified model and personality.

## Contributing

Contributions to AIPersonalityServer are welcome! If you want to contribute, please follow the guidelines outlined in the [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/ParisNeo/lollms/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) file.

## License

AIPersonalityServer is licensed under the Apache 2.0 license. See the [LICENSE](https://github.com/ParisNeo/lollms/blob/main/LICENSE) file for more details.

## Credits

AIPersonalityServer was built by ParisNeo and is available on GitHub at [https://github.com/ParisNeo/lollms](https://github.com/ParisNeo/lollms).

If you encounter any issues or have any questions, please create an issue on the GitHub repository.

class LoLLMsServer:
    def __init__(self):
        self.app = Flask("LoLLMsServer_Server")
        self.app.config['SECRET_KEY'] = 'your-secret-key'
        CORS(self.app)  # Enable CORS for all routes
        self.socketio = SocketIO(self.app)
        self.clients = {}
        self.models = []
        self.personalities = {}
        self.answer = ['']

        # Set log level to warning
        self.app.logger.setLevel(logging.WARNING)
        # Configure a custom logger for Flask-SocketIO
        self.socketio_log = logging.getLogger('socketio')
        self.socketio_log.setLevel(logging.WARNING)
        self.socketio_log.addHandler(logging.StreamHandler())

        self.initialize_routes()

    def initialize_routes(self):
        @self.socketio.on('connect')
        def handle_connect():
            client_id = request.sid
            self.clients[client_id] = {"namespace": request.namespace, "full_discussion_blocks": []}
            print(f'Client connected with session ID: {client_id}')

        @self.socketio.on('disconnect')
        def handle_disconnect():
            client_id = request.sid
            if client_id in self.clients:
                del self.clients[client_id]
            print(f'Client disconnected with session ID: {client_id}')

        @self.socketio.on('list_personalities')
        def handle_list_personalities():
            personality_names = list(self.personalities.keys())
            emit('personalities_list', {'personalities': personality_names}, room=request.sid)

        @self.socketio.on('add_personality')
        def handle_add_personality(data):
            personality_path = data['path']
            try:
                personality = AIPersonality(personality_path)
                self.personalities[personality.name] = personality
                emit('personality_added', {'name': personality.name}, room=request.sid)
            except Exception as e:
                error_message = str(e)
                emit('personality_add_failed', {'error': error_message}, room=request.sid)

        @self.socketio.on('generate_text')
        def handle_generate_text(data):
            model = self.models[0]
            client_id = request.sid
            prompt = data['prompt']
            personality: AIPersonality = self.personalities[data['personality']]
            # Placeholder code for text generation
            # Replace this with your actual text generation logic
            print(f"Text generation requested by client: {client_id}")

            self.answer[0] = ''
            full_discussion_blocks = self.clients[client_id]["full_discussion_blocks"]

            def callback(text, message_type: MSG_TYPE):
                if message_type == MSG_TYPE.MSG_TYPE_CHUNK:
                    self.answer[0] = self.answer[0] + text
                    emit('text_chunk', {'chunk': text}, room=client_id)
                return True

            if personality.processor is not None and personality.processor_cfg["process_model_input"]:
                preprocessed_prompt = personality.processor.process_model_input(prompt)
            else:
                preprocessed_prompt = prompt

            full_discussion_blocks.append(personality.user_message_prefix)
            full_discussion_blocks.append(preprocessed_prompt)
            full_discussion_blocks.append(personality.link_text)
            full_discussion_blocks.append(personality.ai_message_prefix)

            full_discussion = personality.personality_conditioning + ''.join(full_discussion_blocks)

            print(f"---------------- Input prompt -------------------")
            print(f"{color_green}{full_discussion}")
            print(f"{color_reset}--------------------------------------------")
            if personality.processor is not None and personality.processor_cfg["custom_workflow"]:
                print("processing...", end="", flush=True)
                generated_text = personality.processor.run_workflow(prompt, full_discussion, callback=callback)
            else:
                print("generating...", end="", flush=True)
                generated_text = model.generate(full_discussion, n_predict=personality.model_n_predicts,
                                                callback=callback)
            full_discussion_blocks.append(generated_text)
            print(f"{color_green}ok{color_reset}", end="", flush=True)

            # Emit the generated text to the client
            emit('text_generated', {'text': generated_text}, room=client_id)

    def build_model(self, bindings_path: Path, cfg: BindingConfig):
        binding_path = Path(bindings_path) / cfg["binding_name"]
        # first find out if there is a requirements.txt file
        install_file_name = "install.py"
        install_script_path = binding_path / install_file_name
        if install_script_path.exists():
            module_name = install_file_name[:-3]  # Remove the ".py" extension
            module_spec = importlib.util.spec_from_file_location(module_name, str(install_script_path))
            module = importlib.util.module_from_spec(module_spec)
            module_spec.loader.exec_module(module)
            if hasattr(module, "Install"):
                module.Install(self.config)
        # define the full absolute path to the module
        absolute_path = binding_path.resolve()
        # infer the module name from the file path
        module_name = binding_path.stem
        # use importlib to load the module from the file path
        loader = importlib.machinery.SourceFileLoader(module_name, str(absolute_path / "__init__.py"))
        binding_module = loader.load_module()
        binding_class = getattr(binding_module, binding_module.binding_name)

        model = binding_class(cfg)
        return model

    def run(self, host="localhost", port="9600"):
        parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
        parser.add_argument('--host', '-hst', default=host, help='Host name')
        parser.add_argument('--port', '-prt', default=port, help='Port number')

        parser.add_argument('--bindings_path', '-bp', default=str(Path(__file__).parent / "bindings_zoo"),

                            default=str(Path(__file__).parent / "personalities_zoo"),

        parser.add_argument('--models_path', '-mp', default=str(Path(__file__).parent / "models"),
                            help='The path to the models folder')

                            help='Binding to be used by default')
        parser.add_argument('--model_name', '-m', default="Manticore-13B.ggmlv3.q4_0.bin",
                            help='Model name')
        parser.add_argument('--personality_full_name', '-p', default="personality",
                            help='Personality path relative to the personalities folder (language/category/name)')

        args = parser.parse_args()

# Lord of Large Language Models (LoLLMs) Server

![Lord of Large Language Models](https://github.com/ParisNeo/lollms/blob/main/logo.png)

Lord of Large Language Models (LoLLMs) Server is a text generation server based on large language models. It provides a Flask-based API for generating text using various pre-trained language models. This server is designed to be easy to install and use, allowing developers to integrate powerful text generation capabilities into their applications.

## Features

- Generate text using large language models.
- Supports multiple personalities for generating text with different styles and tones.
- Real-time text generation with WebSocket-based communication.
- RESTful API for listing personalities and adding new personalities.
- Easy integration with various applications and frameworks.

## Installation

You can install LoLLMs Server using pip, the Python package manager. Open your terminal or command prompt and run the following command:

```
pip install lollms-server
```

## Usage

Once installed, you can start the LoLLMs Server using the `lollms-server` command followed by the desired parameters.

```
lollms-server --host <host> --port <port> --config <config_file> --bindings_path <bindings_path> --personalities_path <personalities_path> --models_path <models_path> --binding_name <binding_name> --model_name <model_name> --personality_full_name <personality_full_name>
```

### Parameters

- `--host`: The hostname or IP address to bind the server (default: localhost).
- `--port`: The port number to run the server (default: 9600).
- `--config`: Path to the configuration file (default: None).
- `--bindings_path`: The path to the Bindings folder (default: "./bindings_zoo").
- `--personalities_path`: The path to the personalities folder (default: "./personalities_zoo").
- `--models_path`: The path to the models folder (default: "./models").
- `--binding_name`: The default binding to be used (default: "llama_cpp_official").
- `--model_name`: The default model name (default: "Manticore-13B.ggmlv3.q4_0.bin").
- `--personality_full_name`: The full name of the default personality (default: "personality").

### Examples

Start the server with default settings:

```
lollms-server
```

Start the server on a specific host and port:

```
lollms-server --host 0.0.0.0 --port 5000
```

## API Endpoints

### WebSocket Events

- `connect`: Triggered when a client connects to the server.
- `disconnect`: Triggered when a client disconnects from the server.
- `list_personalities`: List all available personalities.
- `add_personality`: Add a new personality to the server.
- `generate_text`: Generate text based on the provided prompt and selected personality.

### RESTful API

- `GET /personalities`: List all available personalities.
- `POST /personalities`: Add a new personality to the server.

## Contributing

Contributions to the LoLLMs Server project are welcome and appreciated. If you would like to contribute, please follow the guidelines outlined in the [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/ParisNeo/lollms/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) file.

## License

LoLLMs Server is licensed under the Apache 2.0 License. See the [LICENSE](https://github.com/ParisNeo/lollms/blob/main/LICENSE) file for more information.

## Repository

from lollms import AIPersonality, lollms_path
from lollms.binding import BindingConfig
import lollms.bindings_zoo.llama_cpp_official as llm_binding
import lollms.bindings_zoo.llama_cpp_official.install as llm_binding_installer
import shutil

# Install binding if not installed yet 
def build_model(cfg: BindingConfig):
    llm_binding_installer.Install(cfg)
    model = llm_binding.LLAMACPP(cfg)
    return model

# Set up the model and personality
def setup_model(url, personality_path):
    model_name = url.split("/")[-1]

    original = lollms_path / "configs/config.yaml"
    local = lollms_path / "configs/config_local.yaml"
    if not local.exists():
        shutil.copy(original, local)
    cfg_path = local

    cfg = BindingConfig(cfg_path)
    cfg.binding_name = llm_binding.binding_folder_name
    cfg.model_name = model_name
    if not cfg.check_model_existance():
        cfg.download_model(url)

    model = build_model(cfg)
    personality = AIPersonality(lollms_path / "personalities_zoo" / personality_path, model)

    return model, personality

# Start the conversation loop
def start_conversation(personality):
    full_discussion = (
        personality.personality_conditioning +
        personality.ai_message_prefix +
        personality.welcome_message +
        personality.link_text
    )

    while True:
        try:
            prompt = input("You: ")
            if prompt == '':
                continue

            if personality.processor is not None:
                preprocessed_prompt = personality.processor.process_model_input(prompt)

                full_discussion += (
                    personality.user_message_prefix +
                    preprocessed_prompt +
                    personality.link_text +
                    personality.ai_message_prefix
                )
            else:
                full_discussion += (
                    personality.user_message_prefix +
                    prompt +
                    personality.link_text +
                    personality.ai_message_prefix
                )

            print(f"{personality.name}:", end='')

            def callback(text, type=None):
                print(text, end="", flush=True)
                return True

            output = model.generate(full_discussion, callback=callback)
            print("\n")

            if personality.processor is not None:
                if personality.processor.process_model_output is not None:
                    output = personality.processor.process_model_output(output)

        except KeyboardInterrupt:
            print("Keyboard interrupt detected.\nBye")
            break

    print("Done")
    print(f"{personality}")

# Main program
if __name__ == "__main__":
    # Choose your model (uncomment the model you want to use)
    url = "https://huggingface.co/TheBloke/Manticore-13B-GGML/resolve/main/Manticore-13B.ggmlv3.q4_0.bin"
    personality_path = "english/generic/lollms"

    model, personality = setup_model(url, personality_path)

    # If there is a disclaimer, show it
    if personality.disclaimer != "":
        print("\nDisclaimer")
        print(personality.disclaimer)
        print()

    if personality.welcome_message:
        print(personality.welcome_message)

    start_conversation(personality)

How to add the variable environment?

To add a variable environment to your code, you can use the `env` parameter of the `subprocess.run()` function. Here's an example of how you can modify your code to include a variable environment:

```python
import subprocess

# Define the environment variables
env = {"MY_VARIABLE": "my_value", "ANOTHER_VARIABLE": "another_value"}

# Specify the command and arguments
command = ["pip", "install", "--no-cache-dir", "-r", str(requirements_file)]

# Run the command with the specified environment
subprocess.run(command, env=env)
```

In the `env` dictionary, you can add as many environment variables as needed, each represented as a key-value pair. Replace `"MY_VARIABLE"` and `"ANOTHER_VARIABLE"` with the actual names of your environment variables, and `"my_value"` and `"another_value"` with their respective values.

By passing the `env` parameter to `subprocess.run()`, the command will be executed within the specified environment, allowing you to set the necessary variables for your wheel-building process.

# Regular colors

# Bright colors

color_bright_red = '\u001b[31;1m'

color_bright_blue = '\u001b[34;1m'
color_bright_magenta = '\u001b[35;1m'
color_bright_cyan = '\u001b[36;1m'
color_bright_white = '\u001b[37;1m'


# Store connected clients
clients = {}
models = []
personalities = {}
answer = ['']

def build_model(bindings_path:Path, cfg: BindingConfig):
    binding_path = Path(bindings_path)/cfg["binding"]
    # first find out if there is a requirements.txt file
    install_file_name="install.py"
    install_script_path = binding_path / install_file_name        
    if install_script_path.exists():
        module_name = install_file_name[:-3]  # Remove the ".py" extension
        module_spec = importlib.util.spec_from_file_location(module_name, str(install_script_path))
        module = importlib.util.module_from_spec(module_spec)
        module_spec.loader.exec_module(module)
        if hasattr(module, "Install"):
            module.Install(None)
    # define the full absolute path to the module
    absolute_path = binding_path.resolve()            
    # infer the module name from the file path
    module_name = binding_path.stem    
    # use importlib to load the module from the file path
    loader = importlib.machinery.SourceFileLoader(module_name, str(absolute_path/"__init__.py"))
    binding_module = loader.load_module()
    binding_class = getattr(binding_module, binding_module.binding_name)

    model = binding_class(cfg)
    return model

    emit('personalities_list', {'personalities': personality_names}, room=request.sid)

@socketio.on('add_personality')

    personality_path = data['path']
    try:
        personality = AIPersonality(personality_path)
        personalities[personality.name] = personality
        emit('personality_added', {'name': personality.name}, room=request.sid)
    except Exception as e:
        error_message = str(e)
        emit('personality_add_failed', {'error': error_message}, room=request.sid)


@socketio.on('generate_text')
def handle_generate_text(data):
    model = models[0]
    client_id = request.sid
    prompt = data['prompt']
    personality:AIPersonality = personalities[data['personality']]
    # Placeholder code for text generation
    # Replace this with your actual text generation logic
    print(f"Text generation requested by client :{client_id}")

    answer[0]=''
    full_discussion_blocks = clients[client_id]["full_discussion_blocks"]
    def callback(text, messsage_type:MSG_TYPE):
        if messsage_type==MSG_TYPE.MSG_TYPE_CHUNK:
            answer[0]  = answer[0] + text
            emit('text_chunk', {'chunk': text}, room=client_id)
        return True
    
    if personality.processor is not None and personality.processor_cfg["process_model_input"]:
        preprocessed_prompt = personality.processor.process_model_input(prompt)
    else:
        preprocessed_prompt = prompt
        
    full_discussion_blocks.append(personality.user_message_prefix)
    full_discussion_blocks.append(preprocessed_prompt)
    full_discussion_blocks.append(personality.link_text)
    full_discussion_blocks.append(personality.ai_message_prefix)
        
    full_discussion = personality.personality_conditioning + ''.join(full_discussion_blocks)
    
    print(f"---------------- Input prompt -------------------")
    print(f"{color_green}{full_discussion}")
    print(f"{color_reset}--------------------------------------------")
    if personality.processor is not None and personality.processor_cfg["custom_workflow"]:
        print("processing...",end="",flush=True)
        generated_text = personality.processor.run_workflow(prompt, full_discussion, callback=callback)
    else:
        print("generating...",end="",flush=True)
        generated_text = model.generate(full_discussion, n_predict=personality.model_n_predicts, callback=callback)
    full_discussion_blocks.append(generated_text)
    print(f"{color_green}ok{color_reset}",end="",flush=True)    

    
    # Emit the generated text to the client
    emit('text_generated', {'text': generated_text}, room=client_id)

    if cfg_path.exists():

i have a python project and want to make an install for it, but it  needs some asets

To create an installable package for your Python project, you can use a tool like `setuptools` along with `pip` to manage dependencies and include your assets. Here's a step-by-step guide on how to achieve this:

1. Directory Structure:
   Ensure your project follows a standard directory structure. For example:
   ```
   myproject/
   ├── myproject/
   │   ├── __init__.py
   │   └── mymodule.py
   ├── assets/
   │   ├── asset1.txt
   │   └── asset2.txt
   ├── setup.py
   └── README.md
   ```

2. Create a `setup.py` file:
   In your project's root directory, create a file named `setup.py`. This file will define the installation configuration. Here's a basic example:

   ```python
   from setuptools import setup

   setup(
       name='myproject',
       version='1.0',
       packages=['myproject'],
       include_package_data=True,
       install_requires=[
           'dependency1',
           'dependency2',
           # List your project's dependencies here
       ],
       package_data={
           '': ['*.txt']  # Include all text files from the root directory
       },
   )
   ```

   Adjust the `name`, `version`, `packages`, `install_requires`, and `package_data` fields to match your project's details.

3. Include your assets:
   In the `package_data` field of `setup.py`, specify the patterns for including your assets. The example above includes all `*.txt` files from the root directory. Modify it based on your asset types and directory structure.

4. Build the package:
   Open a terminal or command prompt and navigate to the root directory of your project. Run the following command to build the package:

   ```shell
   python setup.py sdist
   ```

   This command will create a `dist` directory containing the package distribution file (e.g., `myproject-1.0.tar.gz`).

5. Install the package:
   To test the installation, create a virtual environment (recommended) and install your package using `pip`. In the terminal, navigate to a directory where you want to test the installation and run:

   ```shell
   python -m venv myenv  # Create a virtual environment (optional)
   source myenv/bin/activate  # Activate the virtual environment (optional)
   pip install /path/to/myproject/dist/myproject-1.0.tar.gz
   ```

   Replace `/path/to/myproject/dist/myproject-1.0.tar.gz` with the actual path to your package distribution file.

6. Access your assets:
   Once your project is installed, you can access your assets using relative paths. Assuming you have a module named `mymodule.py` in the `myproject` package, you can access an asset like this:

   ```python
   import os

   def read_asset(filename):
       asset_path = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), '..', 'assets', filename)
       with open(asset_path, 'r') as file:
           return file.read()

   asset_content = read_asset('asset1.txt')
   print(asset_content)
   ```

   The `read_asset` function constructs the absolute path to your asset, assuming it is in the `assets` directory relative to the current module's location.

By following these steps, you can create an installable package for your Python project that includes your assets.

import sys
from PyQt5.QtGui import QIcon
from PyQt5.QtCore import QObject, pyqtSignal, pyqtSlot
from PyQt5.QtWidgets import QApplication, QMainWindow, QTextEdit,QHBoxLayout, QLineEdit, QVBoxLayout, QWidget, QToolBar, QAction, QPushButton, QStatusBar, QComboBox
from PyQt5.QtSvg import QSvgWidget
from socketio.client import Client
from socketio.exceptions import ConnectionError
from pathlib import Path

class ServerConnector(QObject):
    text_chunk_received = pyqtSignal(str)
    text_generated = pyqtSignal(str)
    connection_failed = pyqtSignal()
    connection_status_changed = pyqtSignal(bool)
    personalities_received = pyqtSignal(list)

    def __init__(self, parent=None):
        super(ServerConnector, self).__init__(parent)
        self.socketio = Client()
        self.connected = False
        self.personalities = []
        self.selected_personality = "default_personality"

        self.socketio.on('connect', self.handle_connect)
        self.socketio.on('text_chunk', self.handle_text_chunk)
        self.socketio.on('text_generated', self.handle_text_generated)
        self.socketio.on('personalities_list', self.handle_personalities_received)

    def handle_connect(self):
        self.socketio.emit('connect')

    def connect_to_server(self):
        if not self.connected:
            try:
                self.socketio.connect('http://localhost:9600')
                self.connected = True
                self.connection_status_changed.emit(True)
                self.list_personalities()
            except ConnectionError:
                self.connection_failed.emit()
                self.connection_status_changed.emit(False)

    def disconnect_from_server(self):
        if self.connected:
            self.socketio.disconnect()
            self.connected = False
            self.connection_status_changed.emit(False)

    def list_personalities(self):
        self.socketio.emit('list_personalities')

    @pyqtSlot(str)
    def generate_text(self, prompt):
        if not self.connected:
            self.connection_failed.emit()
            return

        data = {
            'client_id': self.socketio.sid,
            'prompt': prompt,
            'personality': self.selected_personality
        }
        self.socketio.emit('generate_text', data)

    def handle_personalities_list(self, data):
        personalities = data['personalities']
        self.personalities_list_received.emit(personalities)


    def handle_text_chunk(self, data):
        chunk = data['chunk']
        self.text_chunk_received.emit(chunk)

    def handle_text_generated(self, data):
        text = data['text']
        self.text_generated.emit(text)

    def handle_personalities_received(self, data):
        print("Received List of personalities")
        personalities = data['personalities']
        self.personalities = personalities
        self.personalities_received.emit(personalities)

class MainWindow(QMainWindow):
    def __init__(self, parent=None):
        super(MainWindow, self).__init__(parent)
        self.setWindowTitle("AIPersonality Client")

        self.user_input_layout = QHBoxLayout()
        self.user_text = QLineEdit()
        self.text_edit = QTextEdit()
        self.toolbar = QToolBar()
        self.submit_button = QPushButton("Submit")
        self.user_input_layout.addWidget(self.user_text)
        self.user_input_layout.addWidget(self.submit_button)

        self.statusbar = QStatusBar()
        self.personality_combo_box = QComboBox()
        self.personality_combo_box.setMinimumWidth(500)

        self.connect_action = QAction(QIcon(str(Path(__file__).parent/'assets/connected.svg')), "", self)
        self.connect_action.setCheckable(True)
        self.connect_action.toggled.connect(self.toggle_connection)

        self.toolbar.addAction(self.connect_action)
        self.toolbar.addWidget(self.personality_combo_box)
        self.addToolBar(self.toolbar)

        layout = QVBoxLayout()
        layout.addLayout(self.user_input_layout)
        layout.addWidget(self.text_edit)

        widget = QWidget()
        widget.setLayout(layout)
        self.setCentralWidget(widget)

        self.connector = ServerConnector()
        self.connector.text_chunk_received.connect(self.handle_text_chunk)
        self.connector.text_generated.connect(self.handle_text_generated)
        self.connector.connection_failed.connect(self.handle_connection_failed)
        self.connector.connection_status_changed.connect(self.handle_connection_status_changed)
        self.connector.personalities_received.connect(self.handle_personalities_received)
        self.connector.connect_to_server()

        self.submit_button.clicked.connect(self.submit_text)

        self.setStatusBar(self.statusbar)
        self.update_statusbar()

    @pyqtSlot(bool)
    def toggle_connection(self, checked):
        if checked:
            self.connector.connect_to_server()
            self.connect_action.setIcon(QIcon(str(Path(__file__).parent/'assets/connected.svg')))
        else:
            self.connector.disconnect_from_server()
            self.connect_action.setIcon(QIcon(str(Path(__file__).parent/'assets/disconnected.svg'))) 

    @pyqtSlot()
    def submit_text(self):
        prompt = self.user_text.text()
        self.selected_personality = self.personality_combo_box.currentText()
        self.text_edit.insertPlainText("User:"+prompt+"\n"+self.selected_personality+":")
        self.connector.generate_text(prompt)

    @pyqtSlot(str)
    def handle_text_chunk(self, chunk):
        self.text_edit.insertPlainText(chunk)

    @pyqtSlot(str)
    def handle_text_generated(self, text):
        pass#self.text_edit.append(text)

    @pyqtSlot()
    def handle_connection_failed(self):
        self.text_edit.append("Failed to connect to the server.")

    @pyqtSlot(bool)
    def handle_connection_status_changed(self, connected):
        if connected:
            self.statusbar.showMessage("Connected to the server")
        else:
            self.statusbar.showMessage("Disconnected from the server")

    @pyqtSlot(list)
    def handle_personalities_received(self, personalities):
        self.personality_combo_box.clear()
        self.personality_combo_box.addItems(personalities)

    def update_statusbar(self):
        if self.connector.connected:
            self.statusbar.showMessage("Connected to the server")
            self.connect_action.setIcon(QIcon(str(Path(__file__).parent/'assets/connected.svg')))
        else:
            self.statusbar.showMessage("Disconnected from the server")
            self.connect_action.setIcon(QIcon(str(Path(__file__).parent/'assets/disconnected.svg'))) 

if __name__ == '__main__':
    app = QApplication(sys.argv)

should i serve the file? I am just using the html file

If you are just using the HTML file locally without serving it from a web server, you might encounter issues related to the same-origin policy. Browsers enforce stricter security measures for XMLHttpRequest and WebSocket connections when loading HTML files directly from the local filesystem.

To avoid these issues, it is recommended to serve the HTML file using a web server, even if it's a local server. This way, the file will be served over the HTTP protocol, and you won't run into the same-origin policy restrictions.

You can use a simple HTTP server to serve your HTML file locally. Here's an example using Python's built-in `http.server` module:

1. Open a terminal or command prompt.
2. Navigate to the directory containing your HTML file.
3. Run the following command:

   ```shell
   python -m http.server
   ```

4. The server will start running, and you will see an output similar to:

   ```shell
   Serving HTTP on 0.0.0.0 port 8000 (http://0.0.0.0:8000/) ...
   ```

5. Open your web browser and access the URL provided by the server (e.g., `http://localhost:8000`). You should be able to load and run the HTML file without encountering the origin-related issues.

By serving the HTML file using a local server, you ensure that the file is loaded over HTTP, which allows the WebSocket connection to be established without any origin restrictions.

how to use this parameter:
parser.add_argument('--personalities', '-p', nargs='+', default=[], help='A list of path to the personalites folders')

The parameter `--personalities` (or `-p` for short) is an optional command-line argument that can be used with a Python script that uses the argparse module. It allows you to specify one or more paths to folders containing personalities.

Here's how you can use this parameter:

1. Specify the path(s) to the personality folder(s) when running the script from the command line. The `nargs='+'` argument allows you to specify multiple values for this parameter. For example:

```
python your_script.py --personalities /path/to/personality_folder1 /path/to/personality_folder2
```

In the above example, we are specifying two personality folders: `/path/to/personality_folder1` and `/path/to/personality_folder2`.

2. In your Python script, you need to parse the command-line arguments using the `argparse` module. Make sure you have imported the `argparse` module at the beginning of your script. Here's an example of how you can use the `argparse` module to access the `--personalities` parameter:

```python
import argparse

# Create the argument parser
parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
parser.add_argument('--personalities', '-p', nargs='+', default=[], help='A list of paths to the personalities folders')

# Parse the command-line arguments
args = parser.parse_args()

# Access the personalities parameter value
personalities = args.personalities

# Now you can use the 'personalities' variable in your script
```

In the above example, after parsing the arguments, the `args.personalities` variable will contain a list of paths to the personality folders specified on the command line.

You can then use the `personalities` variable in your script to access the paths to the personality folders and perform the desired operations.

Note that the `default=[]` argument sets the default value of `personalities` to an empty list if the parameter is not specified on the command line.
Write a cheatsheet for compiling a python package and send it tp pipy

Sure! Here's a cheatsheet for compiling a Python package and uploading it to PyPI (Python Package Index):

1. Prepare Your Package:
   - Create a directory for your package.
   - Place all the necessary files and code within this directory.
   - Make sure your package has a unique name and a proper directory structure.
   - Include a `setup.py` file in the root of your package directory. This file contains metadata about your package and instructions for building and installing it.

2. Set Up `setup.py`:
   - Open the `setup.py` file in a text editor.
   - Import the necessary modules: `setuptools` and `setuptools.setup`.
   - Define the metadata for your package, such as name, version, description, author, etc.
   - Specify the package dependencies (if any) in the `install_requires` parameter.
   - Include any additional configuration or setup instructions as required.

3. Build Your Package:
   - Open a command prompt or terminal window.
   - Navigate to the root directory of your package where the `setup.py` file is located.
   - Run the following command to build your package: `python setup.py sdist bdist_wheel`.
     - This will create a source distribution (`sdist`) and a wheel distribution (`bdist_wheel`) of your package.
   - After a successful build, you will find the built distributions in the `dist` directory within your package folder.

4. Register and Upload to PyPI:
   - Open a browser and go to https://pypi.org/.
   - Sign in or create an account if you don't have one.
   - Once logged in, click on "Submit" at the top-right corner of the page.
   - Fill in the required information about your package, such as name, version, description, etc.
   - Upload your package distribution files (`.tar.gz` or `.whl`) using the form provided.
   - After uploading, verify that all the information is correct, and then click on "Submit" to publish your package to PyPI.

5. Verify and Install:
   - Once your package is successfully uploaded to PyPI, it may take a few minutes for it to become available.
   - To install your package, open a command prompt or terminal and run: `pip install your-package-name`.
   - Verify the installation by importing your package in a Python script or interactive session.

That's it! You have now created and uploaded your Python package to PyPI. Users can now easily install your package using `pip`.
use twine

Apologies for the oversight. To upload your Python package to PyPI using Twine, follow this updated cheatsheet:

1. Prepare Your Package:
   - Create a directory for your package.
   - Place all the necessary files and code within this directory.
   - Make sure your package has a unique name and a proper directory structure.
   - Include a `setup.py` file in the root of your package directory. This file contains metadata about your package and instructions for building and installing it.

2. Set Up `setup.py`:
   - Open the `setup.py` file in a text editor.
   - Import the necessary modules: `setuptools` and `setuptools.setup`.
   - Define the metadata for your package, such as name, version, description, author, etc.
   - Specify the package dependencies (if any) in the `install_requires` parameter.
   - Include any additional configuration or setup instructions as required.

3. Build Your Package:
   - Open a command prompt or terminal window.
   - Navigate to the root directory of your package where the `setup.py` file is located.
   - Run the following command to build your package: `python setup.py sdist bdist_wheel`.
     - This will create a source distribution (`sdist`) and a wheel distribution (`bdist_wheel`) of your package.
   - After a successful build, you will find the built distributions in the `dist` directory within your package folder.

4. Install Twine:
   - If you haven't installed Twine, run `pip install twine` to install it.

5. Upload to PyPI using Twine:
   - Open a command prompt or terminal window.
   - Navigate to the root directory of your package where the built distributions are located (the `dist` directory).
   - Run the following command to upload your package to PyPI using Twine: `twine upload dist/*`.
     - This command will upload all the distributions in the `dist` directory.
     - Twine will prompt you to enter your PyPI username and password. Provide the required credentials.
     - If you have enabled two-factor authentication on PyPI, you will be prompted for a one-time password.

6. Verify and Install:
   - Once your package is successfully uploaded to PyPI, it may take a few minutes for it to become available.
   - To install your package, open a command prompt or terminal and run: `pip install your-package-name`.
   - Verify the installation by importing your package in a Python script or interactive session.

That's it! You have now created and uploaded your Python package to PyPI using Twine. Users can now easily install your package using `pip`.

from flask import Flask, render_template, request
from flask_socketio import SocketIO, emit
from flask_cors import CORS
from pyaipersonality import AIPersonality, MSG_TYPE
from pyaipersonality.binding import BindingConfig
import importlib
from pathlib import Path
import argparse
import logging

# Reset
color_reset = '\u001b[0m'

# Regular colors
color_black = '\u001b[30m'
color_red = '\u001b[31m'
color_green = '\u001b[32m'
color_yellow = '\u001b[33m'
color_blue = '\u001b[34m'
color_magenta = '\u001b[35m'
color_cyan = '\u001b[36m'
color_white = '\u001b[37m'

# Bright colors
color_bright_black = '\u001b[30;1m'
color_bright_red = '\u001b[31;1m'
color_bright_green = '\u001b[32;1m'
color_bright_yellow = '\u001b[33;1m'
color_bright_blue = '\u001b[34;1m'
color_bright_magenta = '\u001b[35;1m'
color_bright_cyan = '\u001b[36;1m'
color_bright_white = '\u001b[37;1m'
# Store connected clients
clients = {}
models = []
personalities = {}
answer = []

def build_model(bindings_path:Path, cfg: BindingConfig):
    binding_path = Path(bindings_path)/cfg["binding"]
    # first find out if there is a requirements.txt file
    install_file_name="install.py"
    install_script_path = binding_path / install_file_name        
    if install_script_path.exists():
        module_name = install_file_name[:-3]  # Remove the ".py" extension
        module_spec = importlib.util.spec_from_file_location(module_name, str(install_script_path))
        module = importlib.util.module_from_spec(module_spec)
        module_spec.loader.exec_module(module)
        if hasattr(module, "Install"):
            module.Install(None)
    # define the full absolute path to the module
    absolute_path = binding_path.resolve()            
    # infer the module name from the file path
    module_name = binding_path.stem    
    # use importlib to load the module from the file path
    loader = importlib.machinery.SourceFileLoader(module_name, str(absolute_path/"__init__.py"))
    binding_module = loader.load_module()
    binding_class = getattr(binding_module, binding_module.binding_name)

    model = binding_class(cfg)
    return model

app = Flask("AIPersonality_Server")
app.config['SECRET_KEY'] = 'your-secret-key'
CORS(app)  # Enable CORS for all routes
socketio = SocketIO(app)

# Set log level to warning
app.logger.setLevel(logging.WARNING)
# Configure a custom logger for Flask-SocketIO
socketio_log = logging.getLogger('socketio')
socketio_log.setLevel(logging.WARNING)
socketio_log.addHandler(logging.StreamHandler())


@socketio.on('connect')
def handle_connect():
    client_id = request.sid
    clients[client_id] = {"namespace":request.namespace,"full_discussion_blocks":[]}
    print(f'Client connected with session ID: {client_id}')

@socketio.on('disconnect')
def handle_disconnect():
    client_id = request.sid
    if client_id in clients:
        del clients[client_id]
    print(f'Client disconnected with session ID: {client_id}')


@socketio.on('generate_text')
def handle_generate_text(data):
    model = models[0]
    client_id = request.sid
    prompt = data['prompt']
    personality = personalities[data['personality']]
    # Placeholder code for text generation
    # Replace this with your actual text generation logic
    print(f"Text generation requested by client :{client_id}")

    answer[0]=''
    full_discussion_blocks = clients[client_id]["full_discussion_blocks"]
    def callback(text, messsage_type:MSG_TYPE):
        if messsage_type==MSG_TYPE.MSG_TYPE_CHUNK:
            answer[0]  = answer[0] + text
            emit('text_chunk', {'chunk': text}, room=client_id)
        return True
    
    if personality.processor is not None and personality.processor_cfg["process_model_input"]:
        preprocessed_prompt = personality.processor.process_model_input(prompt)
    else:
        preprocessed_prompt = prompt
        
    full_discussion_blocks.append(personality.user_message_prefix)
    full_discussion_blocks.append(preprocessed_prompt)
    full_discussion_blocks.append(personality.link_text)
    full_discussion_blocks.append(personality.ai_message_prefix)
        
    full_discussion = ''.join(full_discussion_blocks)
    
    print(f"---------------- Input prompt -------------------")
    print(f"{color_green}{full_discussion}")
    print(f"{color_reset}--------------------------------------------")
    print("generating...",end="",flush=True)
    if personality.processor is not None and personality.processor_cfg["custom_workflow"]:
        generated_text = personality.processor.run_workflow(prompt, full_discussion, callback=callback)
    else:
        generated_text = model.generate(full_discussion, n_predict=personality.model_n_predicts, callback=callback)
    full_discussion_blocks.append(generated_text)
    print(f"{color_green}ok{color_reset}",end="",flush=True)    

    
    # Emit the generated text to the client
    emit('text_generated', {'text': generated_text}, room=client_id)

def main():
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser()
    parser.add_argument('--host', '-hst', default="localhost", help='Host name')
    parser.add_argument('--port', '-prt', default="9600", help='Port number')
    parser.add_argument('--config', '-cfg', default="configs/config.yaml", help='Path to the configuration file')
    parser.add_argument('--bindings_path', '-bp', default="bindings_zoo", help='Binding path')
    parser.add_argument('--binding', '-b', default=None, help='Binding value')
    parser.add_argument('--personalities', '-p', nargs='+', default=[], help='A list of path to the personalites folders')
    parser.add_argument('--model_name', '-m', default=None, help='Model name')
    args = parser.parse_args()
    path = Path(args.config)

    print("█       █        █       █▄  ▄█▄  ▄█")
    print("█       █        █       █ ▀▀   ▀▀ █")
    print("█       █        █       █         █")
    print("█▄▄▄▄   █▄▄▄▄▄   █▄▄▄▄   █         █")
    if path.exists():
        cfg = BindingConfig(args.config)
    else:
        cfg = BindingConfig()

    if args.binding:
        cfg.binding = args.binding

    if args.model_name:
        cfg.model = args.model_name
    model = build_model(args.bindings_path, cfg)
    models.append(model)

    personalities["default_personality"]=AIPersonality()
    for p in args.personalities:
        personality = AIPersonality(p)
        personalities[personality.name] = personality

    socketio.run(app, host=args.host, port=args.port)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
